The metal can explanation isn't quite correct. When metal bends back and forth, it doesn't quite "fatigue" as much as it "work hardens". The metal gets harder and harder, until it's too hard to bend anymore and the metal would rather break. So it doesn't get weaker and weaker, it gets harder and harder and therefore more brittle.

Here’s one for you.  I know it works on water but haven’t tried it with milk.  Take a very thin wire and bend it into a spiral. The wires in the center of twist ties (like on loaves of bread) work really well.  Clean all the paper and glue off and make sure it has no finger print residue. The spiral should be such that there are only a few millimeters between wraps.  The wraps should all be in the same plane as much as possible.  Very carefully float the spiral wire on your water (having it all flat in one plane helps accomplish this).  Now place a drop of soap in the center of the spiral and watch what happens.

IDEA for a video: Why is it that when two object, traveling in the same direction at different speeds, approach each other, the faster object "seems" to be accelerating as it approaches and passes the slower object. Is it related to the Doppler Effect, or is it just an optical illusion? I've been wondering this for some time. Example from real life, when traveling on a four lane expressway, when a car going 55mph is being passed by a car going 65mph, the closer the faster car gets, the faster it seems to be moving relative to the slower car. About the soap stuff: The soap doesn't really spread on the surface, more decisive is that the soap molecules get solvated in a special way. They are arranging themselves at the water surface because sticking out the hydrophobic tail (the part afraid of water) into the air is more favorable than solvating it in water.
You can also get a maximum number of soap molecules at the surface, which allows you to calculate how much surface area one soap molecule is occupying (which is surprisingly quite large).
Also, adding more soap at this point leads to some wacky stuff, since the surface can't be occupied anymore but solvating that hydrophobic part is still undesired.

Back in high school physics my prof (I was lucky) had us do an experiment where we estimated the size of a molecule.  The experiment required us to deposit an extremely fine material on the surface of the water, talc or lycopodium powder perhaps?  We then put a drop of a known volume of an oil in the middle of powder.  We'd measure the diameter of the (approximate) circle that formed in the powder.  Given the area of the circle in the powder that the oil displaced & the volume of the oil, one was supposed to calculate the molecular diameter. One reason why the food coloring didn't stretch uniformly in milk like it as it did in water, could be that milk contains of droplets (emulsion) of lipids suspended in water. The dish soap might also interact with those lipid droplets, randomly distributed in milk that could lead to different patterns.

Fun fact: These droplets scatter all spectrum of light so effectively that milk appears to be white.

I would guess that the milk one may have something to do with the specific proteins. In general, proteins are much longer molecules than water so they may prefer to go in the same direction as their neighbors which could cause the start effect. Another possibility is that it is somehow related to milk containing both hydrophobic and hydrophilic compounds. Since we are able to produce each component of milk separately, perhaps someday this could be tested to see exactly what component is causing the observed phenomenon.
